Run Spark RunnableOnService
LGTM
LGTM
Run Dataflow RunnableOnService

@jkff The error is a dependency issue with multiple libraries bringing in `com.google.rpc.Code` class. I am working on ways to resolve it, but it shouldn't block you from reviewing. Would have your comments sooner than later :)
Actually I'm going to cancel that as rely on postcommit, to spare the queue.

@peihe 

1. I think there might be a confusion about the delete error as https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/python/apache_beam/io/gcp/gcsio.py#L197 does raise the error again.

2. I'll implement a check on the source files in the copy function

3. Why is file not found an error ? Should that just be an empty list as that is a valid response for no matches. Throwing an error here doesn't seem right to me.
R: @sb2nov
LGTM

Yes, agree. And same on my box. I'm checking.

Build time (MacBook Pro, skipping tests)
-
**Before:** 02:13 min
**After:** 02:35 min

Jar size (Sum of all jars generated)
-
**Before:** 93.93 MB
**After:** 151.34 MB

@amitsela @aviemzur I reintroduce caching in `EvaluationContext#computeOutputs()` to fix the `ResumeFromCheckpointStreamingTest` tests. On the other hand, I did the workaround removing `PipelineRule` to fix the `StorageLevelTest`. I'm still investigating.

Okay, ran 3xROS and 3xMaven_Install - both run all streaming tests, so total of 6 runs. All green. Do I believe it's totally stable now ? hopeful.

R: @staslev note the changes I made to `SparkPipelineResult` and breaking the `PipelineResult` API, which is up for redesign anyway in [BEAM-849](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-849) and doesn't seem to make complete sense in it's current state (the way I'm using it in `TestSparkRunner` is a good example of how I thought it could be used).
CC: @kennknowles following streaming test issues, this should help stabilize them.
CC: @jkff we chatted over a JIRA about this, so this is using watermarks to force termination of streaming pipelines (or pipelines reading from unbounded sources 😉 ).

Sorry for the delay - this is on my radar and something I'm quite excited about.

@sb2nov 

re: 1.
In Java, we want to throws if it is 404. I am not referring to other delete errors.

2.
We want to avoid to do the same check in every implementation of Beam FileSystem.
So, this is why we introduced a utility function FileSystems.java that built on top of Beam FileSystem.
https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2175

3. (I assume you are referring to match())
If I want to match 10 files in srcFiles, and I do match(srcFiles), what should match() returns if 2 files are missing and 8 files are found?

@peihe 

1. Thanks, I'll address that.

2. Makes sense.

3. I personally don't think match should ever throw an exception if you match with a non-existent path that should return an empty list. Match is a search and not an action. @chamikaramj do you have thoughts about this ?
Thanks for merging @aaltay, will create a separate issue about .tox relocation shortly.

@sb2nov 
re. 3
I also think match should not throw if files are missing. my comment was:
"""
match() should not throw if one file is missing. In Java, we store exceptions inside metadata.
"""

I saw match() returns list of list of FileMetadata.

If one of the pattern is illegal, will match() fails for all patterns?
In Java, MatchResult will store exceptions for each pattern, and defer the throw until users try to get the metadata.

@peihe Got it. I can implement something similar for match in python. Will update the PR in a bit.

So if you have multiple copy commands in the batch. When are errors thrown ?

@aaltay : I'll break this change up by reverting the pom.xml change from this PR.

Quick experiment shows that Debian based distros diverge in naming of pip, therefore it is not safe to change `pip2` to `pip-2.7`:

- CentOS6/EPEL: pip (python 2.6) & pip2 (python 2.6) & pip2.6 (python 2.6)
- CentOS7/EPEL: pip (python 2.7) & pip2 (python 2.7) & pip2.7 (python 2.7)
- Debian7: pip (python 2.7) & pip-2.6 (python 2.6) & pip-2.7 (python 2.7)
- Debian8: pip (python 2.7) & pip2 (python 2.7)
- Debian9: pip (python 2.7) & pip2 (python 2.7)
- Ubuntu1204: pip (python 2.7)
- Ubuntu1404: pip2 (python 2.7)
- Ubuntu1604: pip (python 2.7) & pip2 (python 2.7)
- OS X: pip (python 2.6) & pip2 (python 2.6) & pip2.7 (brew / python 2.7)
- Windows: pip-2.7 (python.org based installer)

Sorry for the inconvenience caused.
